bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 1, 1941

div1.p: Kean agrees with Hench that Kissinger needs to be cared for in a veterans' hospital and recommends one in Indianapolis. He also encloses a copy of a letter he wrote to Ida E. Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 1, 1941
div1.opener:
Copy of letter to Mrs. Kissing inclosed-
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Aug. 1st 1941
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
You will think I am a very
poor correspondent and you are right
but it is not from in difference.
Your letter dated July 16 did not
reach Wash. before the only delivery
on that day which was Sat. so I
went off with Mrs. K. that afternoon
to visit my son Robert Hill Kean in
Richmond and, as no mail was
forwarded to us. I did not see
your letter until I came home
sick on the 28th and as I was
not able to do much writing
when I got better on account of
the extreme heat with high humid-
ity, it is only this morning that
I am able to get to your letter.

I will write today to Mrs. Kissinger
and tell her that the thing to do
is to make application to the repre-
sentative of the Veteran's Bureauadministration to
take charge of Kissinger and fur-
nish him the hospitalization that
he needs. I do not think that
Walter Reed should be mentioned
as an alternative because they do
not accept (except in emergency)
cases of this character, for which
the Veterans BureauAdmin. was created.
For the years just subsequent to the
war Walter Reed did admit Vet. Bureau
cases as they V.A. were not equipped to
care for them, but they supplied W. R.
with funds to get the additional
personnel & nurses &c. required and meet the
other expenses. For a member of years how-
ever the Vet. Bureau has withdrawn this
aid.
3
Since writing the above I have had
a talk over the phone with (Mr. Sam
Rose, no, I am not sure of the name) the
representative at the Veterans Administra-
tion in charge of such matters and
he will mail a blank form of appli-
cation to Mrs. John R. Kissinger
telling her just what to do to get
hospitalization for her husband.
If she wants it she can get it and
if she has any sense at all she should
want it, as all his needs will be met.
(without any expense to her as I understand)
I have just left Dr. R. S. Galbreath
out of it as he does not seem to be
working for the interest of his patient
if he leaves him to be cared for
by an ailing old woman when he
can have the hospitalization that
he needs, for the asking.

Your letter was a perfectly courteous
one and deserved a prompt and cour-
teous answer.

So I am writing her a brief note to
say that I have heard from you
of the calamity that has be fallen
Mr. Kissinger and that it is quite
clear to me that he cannot be
properly cared for in a private
home, I have asked the Veterans
Administration here in Washington
to offer her free hospital care
in Indiana, or elsewhere, a
the service which he has a right to
by law. They will, I imagine, care
for him in Indianapolis and
arrange for his transportation
there. I cannot write more today
